required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluating the Effect of Acupuncture on Pain Relief Using Quantitative Sensory Testing (QST)
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluating the Effect of Acupuncture on Pain Relief Using QST

collaborator.agency: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health (NCCIH)

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to explore a new approach in assessing the effectiveness of acupuncture therapy in the treatment chronic pain conditions.

primary_outcome.measure: Heat Pain Tolerance - Baseline: Maximum Temperature (Heat) That Could be Tolerated by Participants
primary_outcome.description: Changes in response to heat stimulation stated as tolerance to heat. Responses are measured with a quantitative sensory testing (QST) device. Measurements were taken before the course of a 4 week acupuncture treatment schedule.

primary_outcome.measure: Heat Pain Tolerance - Visit 2 or 4: Maximum Temperature (Heat) That Could be Tolerated by Participants
primary_outcome.description: Changes in response to heat stimulation stated as tolerance to heat. Responses are measured with a quantitative sensory testing (QST) device. Measurements were taken during the course of a 4 week acupuncture treatment schedule. Those in the no treatment groups were attending their 2nd visit, which occured on the same timeline as if they were attending the 4th visit as a treatment group subject.

primary_outcome.measure: Heat Pain Tolerance - Visit 3 or 7: Maximum Temperature (Heat) That Could be Tolerated by Participants
primary_outcome.description: Changes in response to heat stimulation stated as tolerance to heat. Responses are measured with a quantitative sensory testing (QST) device. Measurements were taken after the course of a 4 week acupuncture treatment schedule. Those in the no treatment groups were attending their 3rd visit, which occured on the same timeline as if they were attending the 7th visit as a treatment group subject.

primary_outcome.measure: Cold Pain Tolerance - Baseline: Maximum Temperature (Cold) That Could be Tolerated by Participants
primary_outcome.description: Changes in response to cold stimulation stated as tolerance to cold. Responses are measured with a quantitative sensory testing (QST) device. Measurements were taken before the course of a 4 week acupuncture treatment schedule.

primary_outcome.measure: Cold Pain Tolerance - Visit 2 or 4: Maximum Temperature (Cold) That Could be Tolerated by Participants
primary_outcome.description: Changes in response to cold stimulation stated as tolerance to cold. Responses are measured with a quantitative sensory testing (QST) device. Measurements were taken during the course of a 4 week acupuncture treatment schedule. Those in the no treatment groups were attending their 2nd visit, which occured on the same timeline as if they were attending the 4th visit as a treatment group subject.

primary_outcome.measure: Cold Pain Tolerance - Visit 3 or 7: Maximum Temperature (Cold) That Could be Tolerated by Participants
primary_outcome.description: Changes in response to cold stimulation stated as tolerance to cold. Responses are measured with a quantitative sensory testing (QST) device. Measurements were taken after the course of a 4 week acupuncture treatment schedule. Those in the no treatment groups were attending their 3rd visit, which occured on the same timeline as if they were attending the 7th visit as a treatment group subject.

arm_group.description: Healthy volunteers with no neck or back pain who attended 7 visits over 4 weeks and received 6 30 minute acupuncture treatment sessions during visits 2-7.This group received true acupuncture treatment (the needles punctured the skin).

Healthy with no neck or back pain who attended 7 visits over 4 weeks and received 6 30 minute acupuncture treatment sessions during visits 2-7. This group received sham acupuncture treatment (the needles did not puncture the skin).
Healthy volunteers with no neck or back pain who attended 3 visits over 4 weeks and received no sham or true acupuncture treatment.

Volunteers with radiating neck or back pain who attended 7 visits over 4 weeks and received 6 30 minute acupuncture treatment sessions during visits 2-7. This group received true acupuncture treatment (the needles punctured the skin).

Volunteers with radiating neck or back pain who attended 7 visits over 4 weeks and received 6 30 minute acupuncture treatment sessions during visits 2-7. This group received sham acupuncture treatment (the needles did not puncture the skin).
Volunteers with radiating neck or back pain who attended 3 visits over 4 weeks and received no sham or true acupuncture treatment.

intervention.description: Subjects receive 6 acupuncture treatments for neck or back pain.
Subjects receive 6 sham acupuncture treatments for neck or back pain.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Subject will be between ages 18 to 65 years. Both male and female subjects will be recruited.
2. Subject should have had cervical or lumbar radicular pain for at least two months. This requirement is to avoid the uncertainty of an unstable pain condition and to minimize the study variation.
3. Subject has a pain score of 4 or above (Visual Analog Scale (VAS): 0 - 10 from no pain to worst pain).
4. Cervical or lumbar radicular pain will include, but is not limited to, such clinical conditions as disk herniation, spinal stenosis, and post-laminectomy syndrome.
5. For controls, healthy subjects without radicular pain for at least three months will be recruited. *We are no longer accepting healthy volunteers.*
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Subject has detectable sensory deficits at the site of QST. Sensory deficits refer to such conditions resulting from neurological diseases or medical conditions causing peripheral polyneuropathy and sensory changes, which include but are not limited to diabetic neuropathy, alcoholic neuropathy, AIDS neuropathy, severe thyroid disease, and severe liver or kidney disorders.
2. Subject has scar tissue, infection, or acute injury at the site of QST.
3. Subject is on anticoagulation therapy.
4. Subject is pregnant.
5. Subject is tested positive on illicit drugs.

facility.name: MGH Center for Translational Pain Research

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: 254 participants were enrolled in the study and were randomly assigned to one of the 6 study arms at "Visit 1". 6 participants were later found to be ineligible to continue to participate (e.g. drug screen, medical history, no longer interested) further in "Visit 1" and they did not recieve study intervention.

group.title: Healthy - True Acupuncture
group.description: Healthy volunteers with no neck or back pain who attended 7 visits over 4 weeks and received 6 30 minute acupuncture treatment sessions during visits 2-7. This group received true acupuncture treatment (the needles punctured the skin).

group.title: Healthy - Sham Acupuncture
group.description: Healthy with no neck or back pain who attended 7 visits over 4 weeks and received 6 30 minute acupuncture treatment sessions during visits 2-7. This group received sham acupuncture treatment (the needles did not puncture the skin).

group.title: Healthy - No Treatment
group.description: Healthy volunteers with no neck or back pain who attended 3 visits over 4 weeks and received no sham or true acupuncture treatment.

group.title: Pain - True Acupuncture
group.description: Volunteers with radiating neck or back pain who attended 7 visits over 4 weeks and received 6 30 minute acupuncture treatment sessions during visits 2-7. This group received true acupuncture treatment (the needles punctured the skin).

group.title: Pain - Sham Acupuncture
group.description: Volunteers with radiating neck or back pain who attended 7 visits over 4 weeks and received 6 30 minute acupuncture treatment sessions during visits 2-7. This group received sham acupuncture treatment (the needles did not puncture the skin).

group.title: Pain - No Treatment
group.description: Volunteers with radiating neck or back pain who attended 3 visits over 4 weeks and received no sham or true acupuncture treatment.

drop_withdraw_reason.title: Sensory Deficit at Site of QST

outcome.title: Heat Pain Tolerance - Baseline: Maximum Temperature (Heat) That Could be Tolerated by Participants
outcome.description: Changes in response to heat stimulation stated as tolerance to heat. Responses are measured with a quantitative sensory testing (QST) device. Measurements were taken before the course of a 4 week acupuncture treatment schedule.
outcome.population: Primary analysis was performed using the mITT (Modified Intent to Treat) method. Participants who were assigned a group and received their 1st study intervention were included in the analysis.

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse event data was collected throughout the 4 week period that a subject was participating in the study from enrollment to completion/termination of study activities.

event.sub_title: Feeling of heaviness and muscle spasm at site of acupuncture

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
